title: How do British people dress differently than American people? - Quora

response.answer_text: I take this opportunity to share a little of what I’ve learnt from my late mother and her staff over the years. Mum was an haute couture fashion designer who started in the 1950s at Christian Dior’s atelier. Update:— When you’re reading the below, don’t think of it as a “how-to” for British vs. American looks. It is a ‘how-to’ but this is just generally about how British vs. Americans tend to compose their looks to help know the differences in how they dress. Before I get started, I must point out a few things:— The UK and the USA are not monoliths in fashion matters. Fashion differs from city to city in both countries — though there is a grain of truth that American society as a whole tends to be comparatively more ‘fixed’ in both fashion tastes and fashion ‘manoeuverability’ than the UK or anywhere in Europe.The stuff we often come across on this subject — British vs. American fashion differences — is usually very, very stereotyped. The stuff that’s written in any fashion-related publication is actually geared for brand publicity to drive sales in some way.Fashion writing not in the above situation tend to be based on their writers’ own personal experiences or observations — not from actual differences required in a professional design and manufacturing context. VERY GENERALLY SPEAKING If we had to shoehorn things into a monolithic description:— American fashion tastes tend to be somewhat more staid from the standpoint of British or European fashion tastes.‘British’ and ‘European’ tend to be interchangeable, and both tend to be somewhat more adventurous and individualistic from the standpoint of American tastes.The way Mum explained it was:— American ‘fashion’ rides on safety in numbers, which pretty much translates into not sticking out for most ordinary fashion situations.The imagery would be wearing classically cut clothes in traditional clothes in classical colours.British/European ‘fashion’ rides on “being diff’rent” in a well-put-together way and sticking out in a pleasant way for the most number of ‘onlookers.’The imagery would be wearing a clever combination of blues with one singular item that contrasts with the whole blue set-up. BRITISH STYLE BASICS British fashion has always had the reputation of being “fearless” and British people famed for their individualistic — sometimes idiosyncratic — sense of style. The funny thing is that, almost everybody who’s either in the fashion industry or have grown up in both America and UK/Europe tends to say this:— You’re more able to define what ‘fashion’ and ‘style’ might not be only after you’ve come into contact with how North Americans generally dress.This was precisely how I felt when my family relocated from Europe to the USA and then re-relocated back to Europe and the UK. The quintessential British style handiwork is this:— British styling is never looking too ‘polished’ — having an “edge” in an understated way is more important.Of course, a major factor in the British sense of styling is in fact the UK weather. British climate generally allows for the kind of “thrown-on” feel of the so-called “festival look” for year-round wear — the look that one is supposed to have going to an open-air music festival in any given place in the UK. The key British style pieces are these:— Womenswear Floral dress — and the so-called “tea dress” in retro 1950s styleStriped topShortsTights in various coloursPearlsPlimsollsBoots (ankle and long)RainbootsMenswear Two-piece fitted pinstripe suit with double vents (blue, grey)Dress trousers, close-fittingOne funky-coloured pair of dress trousers or denims for casualwearLace-up shoes (at least one pair in black)Both ScarfTrench coat — lined or unlinedLong woollen overcoat — longer than knee-lengthLeather jacket or coatBlazerAnkle bootsThin dress leather gloves in reddish chocolate brownIf we look at those items carefully, it’s just like what Mum said — you could easily mix and match nearly all of the items and still never be out of place stylewise. The key British/European style shops are these for ordinary people:— TopshopMiss SelfridgeRiver IslandAll SaintsPrimarkNew LookZaraH&MHow to summarise the British ‘look’:— Mixing tailored but simple vintage or retro chic with modern designer pieces — the kind of style often seen in British actress Carey Mulligan.Eccentric, fun and edgy from mixing refined girly pieces with ‘tough’ leatherwear in a kind of “festival-chic” style — the kind of thing often seen with British writer, TV personality and designer Alexa Chung.Skinny jeans and ballet flats with different layering and mixing of textures and prints, looking like an off-duty model — in short, Kate Moss most of the time.British style in 5 steps on a budget:— Layering — A leather jacket and a blazer are essential for both men and women. The scarf is more than a utility piece to keep you warm — it’s a layering device. For women, tights are worn all the time.Prepare for rain — The ‘look’ has to look like it’s always ready to deal with rain — which isn’t meteorologically a lot in the UK but feels like that.Edgy pieces — It’s unnecessary to hit the extreme like wearing leather boots with a lace dress. It can be as simple as a studded bracelet with a prom dress — or a leather jacket with your “tea dress.” British style after all these years still retain a punk element.Don’t look too ‘done’ — “I just threw this on” in a thoughtful way is better than a carefully crafted one. It’s like you’re supposed to be always going to a real music festival — looking reasonably nice but no need to get formal or worked-up when you’re in a crowd.Fun and bravery — Keep things simple, but also keep things reasonably individualistic for kicks. Instead of always wearing black tights, sometimes wear loud-print ones.A guy wearing a pair of pink gaberdine trousers with a conservative blazer was Mum’s way of explaining ‘fun’ and ‘bravery.’ AMERICAN STYLE BASICS If you ask any garment manufacturer (as opposed to a fashion designer), you’ll get perhaps a more realistic picture that the quintessential American style is much less focused on trends. The quintessential American handiwork is this:— American style is about comfort and casual-looking. ‘Comfort’ and ‘casual’ are the two absolutely overriding things in American clothing culture since as far back as the end of the American Civil War. People in America dress for comfort, not for ‘impact.’ And it would be better if your comfort doesn’t make you stick out from regular people.Most American girls with any sense of style wear simple pieces with impeccable style — a simple black tanktop or white T-shirt is made to look more interesting with accessories. In my own direct observation of having partly grown up in the USA, American guys and girls back in the 1960s and ’70s really knew their jeans and really know how to rock a pair of them. Americans today still can — just that they don’t quite have the same elan doing it. The key American style pieces are:— Womenswear Tanktop (blue, black, white, greyish-green)Shorts‘Ballet’ slip-ons with practically no heels‘All-purpose, all weather’ thigh-length coat (any material and colour)Menswear Sports jacketThree-piece suit with single or double vents in dark grey (essential)Dress trousers, loose fitting (various colours and fabrics)Both HoodiePlaid shirtWhite dress shirtWhite T-shirtJeansShortsFlipflopsSneakers/trainersCowboy boots — any American can wear this without looking ironicDenim may have French origins (from Nîmes in southern France) but it was America that made it into the world’s most culturally powerful fabric in history. The good news is that Americans have a way of wearing jeans that doesn’t look like it’s a “last resort” — which, I’m very sorry to say, isn’t the case with a lot of Eastern Europeans, Chinese, Japanese, Middle Easterners and Southern Asians. In my experience, I’ve found that only American women are mostly able to dress up in jeans and a pair of heels for a night out. I’ve also found only American men and women can wear denim shirts and tops without looking like the homeless or a prison uniform. How to summarise the American ‘look’:— The “All-American” look is subtle and polished (i.e. ‘effortless’) for the particular occasion. Most importantly, it contains almost nil foreign or ethnic elements and unambiguous ‘gender’ components, according to Mum and her staff. In fashion and styling, North Americans have a lot more one-sidedness in their styling preferences than Europeans do. Americans as a whole have a certain ‘certainty’ about their worldview and this reflects their quintessential history. Be ‘noticed’ rather than draw ‘attention.’Appeal (in very general terms):— American women will find appeal in men in both American and European styles — large men preferably in American style and small/skinny men in European style. American women generally prefer men in slightly looser clothes than the typically European ‘tighter’ tailored fit — but American women dislike men in loose-fitting T-shirts. Muscle in men is a desirable trait.Appeal (in very general terms):— American menfolk tends to prefer women mainly in American styles because of the stereotyped perception of ‘European’ women being ‘difficult’ — yet American guys are happy as a clam when their wives and daughters present themselves on important occasions in European tastes. This is borne out repeatedly for decades in garment orders.Simplicity, timelessness and polished using classic pieces — whether out to the opera house or just walking the dog. For women, the classic pieces show off the figure without being revealing — kind of what we usually see in Jennifer Aniston. Or Jackie O. at the most sophisticated end. For men, we’re really talking about Robert Redford, Paul Newman, Clint Eastwood and James Dean, in that order. Guys, please don’t ask me how to do the “R-N-E-D” look.A laid-back West Coast or Californian casual look that takes some risks (like girly shorts in summer) — kind of what we see in Whitney Port.Doesn’t try to be a style icon but makes a hard-to-ignore ‘statement’ in everything worn that you are ‘The’ All-American Girl/Guy — perhaps easily understood in the form of Katie Holmes and Robert Redford.Katherine Hepburn, period — old Hollywood glamour and menswear-inspired style, and the epitome of taking something simple and uneventful like a plain white buttoned-down shirt and wearing an off-white scarf to make the whole thing look amazing. Very few Americans are able to achieve the Hepburn flavour of looks.The key American style shops are these for ordinary people:— American Eagle OutfittersForever 21Urban OutfittersTargetBanana RepublicThe GapAmerican style in 5 steps on a budget:— Keep it classic — Go for simple pieces in plain colours but wear them in unexpected ways.Invest in ‘your’ key pieces — The average American man and woman is into having an easy-to-navigate wardrobe with fairly fixed ‘coordinates.’ There is no overall must-have American “key pieces” — the key pieces are those that fits you to make “you.”Follow just one trend that fits ‘you’ — Americans are very comfortable in their own style and generally don’t follow more than two trends. In terms of clothing and fashion, the overriding feature of Americans is “think inside the box” and “don’t stick out.”Simple, laid-back, and maybe a little cutesy in the right company — Americans get a lot of flak for having a ‘boring’ sense of style even in purely technical matters of garment construction. That’s because the American masses generally treat “style” as different in meaning from “fashion,” which is true insofar as American society is concerned. Like Mum said, it’s not what you wear — it’s how you wear it.Out-of-the-box style only for out-of-the-box situations — American are not adventurous people in many aspects of life, and ‘fashion’ and ‘styling’ preferences are a reflection of that trait. The local malls anywhere in the USA sell a largely uninspiring, flavourless array of preppy and plaid — because people mostly don’t dress beyond that in daily life, unlike the situation in Europe and the UK. But Americans are more willing (with a little persuading) to go full-board “different” for decidedly “experimental” situations.I’m afraid that’s all I had learnt from Mum and her esteemed staff. Remember, all the foregoing isn’t abut high fashion but ‘styling’ for everyday life.

British people dress more stylish and clothes fit properly. Even if they are poor they have a stigma against scruffiness. Their Asda (Walmart) sells way more stylish George clothes so even less affluent people dress better. I remember being home and the quality in the US for Walmart George products were bad, oversized, unflattering, somewhat gaudy, and forget anything dressy especially for kids. I still wore it because thats all I could afford. Their George is on par and some cases better than JC Penney and Sears. So in a sense cheap stylish clothes is more accessible to them especially in places like Primark. In the US trainers/ tennis shoes, hoodie is a way of life unless you have to get dressed up.The clothes I felt comfortable walking around in, in the US I did not feel comfortable wearing in UK. Simply because I stuck out like a sore thumb. They dress in a more stylish casual way, unless they are teens wearing hoodies and sweats and even they looked properly fitted, and clean, well groomed, nice hair etc. People are well groomed in general of course there are a few who don't but the majority look nice. At night women and men dress well when they head out on the town. I wouldn't be caught dead in a pub wearing a hoodie, and sweats in a pub in UK out in the evening. In America that would be everyone including myself.I could go any place looking like crap to some degree, messy bun, t-shirt, sweat pants in the US and no one really noticed. I have a funny observation. In the US we had TJ Max, this is where my husband would send me to to buy some Polo shirts and we could always find loads for cheap and bring them over to him in England. In the UK they have TK Max (same place) and I've seen one Polo shirt, they are gone off the shelf in seconds. This is because they are more conscientious of name brands. I had no idea what Pandora charms were until I came here. I had little exposure to Lacoste, and other brands I may have heard of but had no idea how popular they are here …Even someone in a council flat still has a Pandora Charm Bracelet.
